title-group.article-title: Dietary fat intake, body composition and blood lipids of university men and women

article-meta.aff: 1Institute of Brain Chemistry and Human Nutrition, London Metropolitan University, London, UK
2Food Biosciences University of Reading, Berkshire, UK

author-notes.corresp: Marita M Neville, London Metropolitan University, 9th Floor Tower Building, 166–220 Holloway Road, London N7 8DB, UK. Email: m.neville@londonmet.ac.uk

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Cardiovascular disease rates are high in the UK, particular in men, and are related to dietary fat intake. We conducted a pilot study to investigate relationships between saturated and unsaturated dietary fat intakes, body composition and blood lipid parameters in Caucasian men and women at university.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: Volunteers (52 men and 52 women; age range 20–50 years) were recruited from staff and students of London Metropolitan University. Dietary intake, body composition, blood pressure and fasting blood glucose and lipids were assessed. Gender differences between the measured variables and their relationships were assessed by Mann–Whitney U-test, and by multi-linear (stepwise) regression, respectively.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Men consumed more saturated fat (29.5 vs 20.5 g/day, p < 0.001), and had elevated levels of glucose (5.34 + 0.74 vs 4.85 + 0.49 mmol/l, p < 0.001), low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol (2.99 + 1.5 vs 2.62+ 0.74 mmol/l, p < 0.05), systolic blood pressure (126.4 + 11.0 vs 112.6 + 17.2 mm/Hg, p < 0.001), and lower high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol (1.41 ± 0.34 vs 1.83 ± 0.43, p < 0.001). Saturated fat was positively associated with total body fat ( p < 0.05), trunk fat ( p < 0.001), HDL cholesterol ( p < 0.05) and systolic blood pressure ( p < 0.001) in women, while in men docosahexaenoic acid and total cholesterol ( p < 0.05), total omega-3 fatty acids and LDL cholesterol ( p < 0.001), total omega-3 fatty acids and triglycerides ( p < 0.01) were positively related. Similar n-3 fatty acid intakes were reported in nutritionally aware students and other university subjects.

sec.title: Conclusions:
sec.p: The data of this study indicate gender-related differences in response to dietary fat, and widespread low compliance with n-3 fatty acid recommendations. Although the men are highly health conscious and physically active, their blood lipid levels are indicative of a risk of cardiovascular disease. In addition to enhanced nutritional education to increase seafood intakes in this age group of men and women, customised dietary and lifestyle advice may be required in the men.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The prevalence of obesity continues to rise in the UK, as in many other Western and industrialised countries (Smith, 2007) and is associated with cardiovascular disease (CVD), mediated through the metabolic syndrome (Reaven, 2005). However, this may not be an inevitable consequence of obesity, because CVD is absent in certain obese, high fat-consuming populations (Fujimoto, 1996; Mavoa and McCabe 2008), and has led researchers to consider the quality, rather than the quantity, of dietary fat (Mozaffarian, 2005; Willett, 2008).

Much is known about the effects of saturated and polyunsaturated fats on lipoproteins, insulin resistance and obesity (Arefhosseini et al., 2009; Balk et al., 2006; Ma et al., 2006). Nevertheless, differences are seen in body composition, and in blood glucose and lipid profiles of pre-menopausal women and men of a similar age (Couchepin et al., 2008) despite apparent similar percentage energy intakes from these fats (Bakewell et al., 2006; Henderson et al., 2002). Compared with women of child-bearing age, men appear to be more at risk for CVD. There is a scarcity of comprehensive published data examining dietary factors relating to this gender disparity.

Current dietary fat recommendations are similar for men and women (Department of Health, 1991), and evaluation of dietary cardioprotection is based on a balance of individual fats. In the UK population, saturated and omega-6 fat intakes are higher than recommendations (Henderson et al., 2002) and dietary omega-3 fatty acids lower than Northern European and Mediterranean countries (Welch et al., 2002). This pilot study investigated the differential effect of habitual dietary fat intake on body composition and biological risk markers for non-communicable chronic diseases in men and women. A homogeneous sample group of nutritionally aware, healthy young men and women enrolled as a potential pilot for a larger study with a less nutritionally aware, lower socioeconomic East London sample population.

sec.title: Subjects and recruitment
sec.p: One hundred and four healthy Caucasian volunteers (52 men and 52 women) aged between 20 and 50 years were recruited from staff and students at London Metropolitan University. Eligibility was assessed using a self-completed questionnaire. The exclusion criteria were pregnancy, breastfeeding, genetic (cystic fibrosis, sickle cell anaemia etc.) and non-communicable chronic (diabetes, hyperlipidaemia, inflammatory bowel disease, multiple sclerosis etc.) medical conditions, and regular consumption of recreational drugs and excessive alcohol. The eligible subjects were invited to a meeting where additional information on the study was provided. Camden and Islington Community Research Ethics Committee approved the study, and written consent was obtained from the volunteers.

sec.title: Dietary assessment
sec.p: The volunteers were asked to record details of all foods and fluids consumed during the 7 consecutive days prior to blood sampling. They were given written and oral instructions on how to complete the diary using household measures, and provided with photographs representing typical sizes for a range of glasses, crockery and cutlery, as well as a series of eight portions of commonly eaten foods to assist in description of food portion sizes. In addition, they were asked to keep food wrappers and containers, so that weights and descriptions of pre-packaged foods eaten could be evaluated. Recipes of frequently consumed dishes, which were not already in the original database, were analysed and added to the database.

Energy and nutrient content of the diets was calculated using FOODBASE, a nutritional analysis program developed by the Institute of Brain Chemistry and Human Nutrition, London Metropolitan University, London, UK. The program is based on the sixth edition of McCance and Widdowson’s The Composition of Foods and its 10 accompanying supplements (Food Standards Agency, 2002) and enhanced fatty acid data produced by the Institute of Brain Chemistry and Human Nutrition. The food diary and nutrition software have been validated previously (Doyle et al., 1992). To eliminate interpersonal variability in assessment of portion sizes, the same experienced dietitian carried out the analysis and interpretation of the food diaries.

sec.title: Anthropometric, body composition and blood pressure measurements
sec.p: Height to the nearest 0.5 cm was measured using a portable stadiometer. Weight, percentage body fat, body fat mass, fat-free mass, predicted muscle mass and basal metabolic rate were measured with the use of body composition analyser (BC-418MA, Tanita Corporation, Tokyo, Japan) (Pietrobelli et al., 2003). The measurements were undertaken with the volunteers wearing light clothing and no shoes. To account for the light clothing, 1 kg was deducted from the weight of the volunteers. Blood pressure was measured twice with the subjects in sitting position with a digital upper arm blood pressure monitor (Omron 705IT, Shiokoji, Kyoto, Japan).

sec.title: Blood collection and processing
sec.p: After an overnight fast, 20 ml of whole blood was collected in EDTA-containing tubes. Plasma and erythrocytes were separated by cold centrifugation at 1500 G for 15 minutes. The plasma layer was carefully removed and transferred into another tube and stored at –70°C until analysis.

sec.title: Analysis of plasma lipids and glucose
sec.p: Plasma total and high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol, triglyceride and glucose were analysed by the use of Ace Alera Clinical Chemistry System (Alfa Wassermann Diagnostic Technologies, GK Woerden, The Netherlands). Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol was computed using the following equation: [LDL cholesterol = total cholesterol (HDL cholesterol + triglyceride/5)].

sec.title: Data analyses
sec.p: The results are presented as means and standard deviations. Data were checked for normality by Shapiro–Wilk normality test and visual inspection of histograms. Differences in the measured variables between the two groups were compared by Mann–Whitney U-test. Associations between variables were by (multiple) linear regression (stepwise method) after normalisation of skewed variables by log transformation. All the calculations were performed by the use of the statistical package SPSS for Windows, Release 16 (SPSS Inc., Chicago, IL, USA).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Dietary, body composition and blood parameter results were available for 100 subjects (49 males, 51 females). Four subjects (3 males, 1 female) who did not complete the food diaries appropriately were excluded. Subject occupations were as follows: 4 male and 18 female nutrition students; 4 male and 5 female sports students; 4 male and 5 female other students; 30 male and 20 female staff; 7 male and 3 female other (external) workers.

sec.title: Anthropometric, clinical and demographic data
sec.p: Anthropometric, clinical and demographic data are presented in Table 1. The men had higher weight, height, fat-free mass, basal metabolic rate and systolic blood pressure (p < 0.001) and lower trunk and body fat ( p < 0.001) than the women. There were no differences in mean age and diastolic blood pressure between the two groups ( p > 0.05).

fn.p: BMI, body mass index (weight/height2), BMR, basal metabolic rate; BP, blood pressure.

sec.title: Energy and macronutrients
sec.p: Dietary energy and macronutrient intakes of the volunteers are shown in Table 2. The men consumed more energy, and absolute carbohydrate, protein and fat, than the women (p < 0.001). However, there were no significant differences in energy, protein and fat consumption between the men and women when the energy and macronutrient intakes were expressed per kilogram of body weight and as a percentage of total energy, respectively.

sec.title: Dietary fatty acids
sec.p: Dietary intake of the fatty acid groups is presented in Table 3. The consumption of saturated ( p < 0.001), polyunsaturated ( p < 0.01), omega-6 ( p < 0.01) and omega-3 (p < 0.05) fatty acids was higher in the men than in the women. However, when the intakes were expressed as percentage energy, only the intake of saturated fatty acids was significantly higher in the men ( p < 0.05).

sec.title: Blood glucose and lipid parameters
sec.p: The levels of blood glucose and lipids are shown in Table 4.

caption.p: Mean glucose and lipid parameters (mean ± SD).

fn.p: HDL, high-density lipoprotein; LDL, low-density lipoprotein.

sec.p: Plasma glucose ( p < 0.001), LDL cholesterol ( p < 0.05) and LDL:HDL ratio ( p < 0.001) were higher, and HDL cholesterol lower ( p < 0.001), in the men than the women. There was no difference in triglyceride level between the two genders ( p > 0.05)

sec.title: Associations between dietary and biological risk markers for chronic diseases
sec.p: Relationships between dietary fat (% energy), body composition, lipoproteins and blood pressure variables are shown in Table 5.

caption.p: Relationships among dietary and body composition variables and biological risk markers for non-communicable chronic diseases.

fn.p: Excluded variables: log% energy intake from ALA.
All variables transformed except for HDL-cholesterol in all subjects and systolic blood pressure in women. All included fatty acids expressed as percentage of energy intakes.

% body fat, percentage of total body fat; % energy, percentage of total energy intake; % trunk fat, percentage of trunk fat; ALA, alpha-linolenic acid; BMI, body mass index; chol, cholesterol; DBP, diastolic blood pressure; DHA, docosahexaenoic acid; FFM, fat-free mass; MUFA, monounsaturated fat; SBP, systolic blood pressure; SFA, saturated fat; TGs, triglycerides.

sec.p: Fat-free mass was positively associated with dietary monounsaturated fatty acid (p < 0.01) in men and, conversely, in women an inverse association with dietary MUFA ( p < 0.05), and positive associations with dietary omega-6 fatty acids ( p < 0.001) and eicosapentaenoic acid (p < 0.05) were found.
Total body and trunk fat were dependent on intake of saturated fat ( p < 0.05, p < 0.001 respectively) in women.
Total cholesterol level was related to dietary docosahexaenoic acid (p < 0.05) in men.
In men, LDL cholesterol was positively associated with dietary omega-3 and negatively associated with dietary omega-6 fatty acids ( p < 0.01 for each).
In women, HDL cholesterol level was positively related to dietary saturated fat intake ( p < 0.05).

Plasma triglyceride level was positively associated with total body fat ( p < 0.05), trunk fat ( p < 0.05) and dietary omega-3 fatty acids ( p < 0.01), and negatively with dietary omega-6 fatty acids ( p < 0.05).

Systolic blood pressure was dependent on body mass index (BMI; p < 0.05) in men and, in contrast, inversely related to dietary MUFA ( p < 0.01) and positively related to dietary saturated fat ( p < 0.05) in women.
Diastolic blood pressure was dependent on total body fat ( p < 0.05) in men, and on BMI in women ( p < 0.05).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We found that, in this sample of educated young Londoners, men consumed more energy and absolute but not proportional amounts of protein, carbohydrate and fat than women. The contribution of polyunsaturated fatty acids to total energy intake was close to population recommendations of 6% (Department of Health, 1991), but the combined intake of EPA and DHA was lower than UK recommendations of 0.45 g/day (SACN, 2004) and European recommendations of 0.5 g/day (International Society for the Study of Fatty Acids and Lipids, 2004).

The assessment of nutrient intakes by estimated food diary is not as robust as other methods (Bingham et al., 1995), so food portion size photographs were used for greater accuracy. Our findings are broadly in line with results of weighed intakes from the National Diet and Nutrition Survey (Henderson et al., 2002): similar percentages of men and women achieved the estimated average requirements for energy; proportional energy intakes from carbohydrate and fat, percentage energy intakes from carbohydrate and fibre intakes were below recommendations (Department of Health, 1991). Participants in our study consumed less saturated fat, possibly reflecting the fact that many had an interest in nutritional issues, although surprisingly fewer omega-3 fatty acids than national averages (Henderson et al., 2002).

The current findings indicate that qualitative fat intake appears to influence body composition. We found that women with higher total body and trunk fat reported a higher dietary intake of saturated as opposed to total fat, in line with findings from earlier (Romieu et al., 1988) and more recent studies (Bes-Rastrollo et al., 2008; Savage et al., 2008). In particular, such trunk fat changes may increase risk for conditions associated with the metabolic syndrome (Båvenholm, 2003; Kopelman, 1997). In contrast, dietary omega-6 was related to fat-free mass in similar way to findings from a recent study (Norris et al., 2009). In addition, in our female subjects, dietary EPA was related to fat-free mass, a finding which is supported by evidence from animal (Bueno et al., 2008) and human studies (Micallef et al., 2009; Sneddon et al., 2008). Surprisingly, there were gender differences in the relationship of dietary MUFA to fat-free mass, although sex disparities in effect of dietary fat on body composition have been reported previously (Kien and Bunn, 2008).

Consistent with previous reports (Hazzard, 1985; Magkos et al., 2008), we found gender variations in some parameters, despite similar alcohol and exercise levels: triglycerides, LDL cholesterol and systolic blood pressure were higher in men and HDL cholesterol level was higher in women. Surprisingly, although the women had higher trunk and total body fat than men, female systolic blood pressure was lower. This has been reported before (Gupta and Kapoor, 2010), and may be because of an oestrogenic effect (Mendelsohn and Karras, 1999), or because in women a greater degree of adiposity and higher lipid risk profile is required before adverse effects on blood pressure are observed (Depres et al., 1985). In addition, as reported in earlier studies, there were associations between dietary fats and lipoprotein levels, although gender differences in response to dietary fats were apparent. LDL cholesterol was negatively correlated with dietary omega-6 (Mattson and Grundy, 1985), and total cholesterol was positively associated with DHA intake. Despite a scarcity of information regarding the gene–nutrient interaction, it is known that dietary DHA increases both HDL and LDL (Bays et al., 2008) especially in Apo-E4 carriers (Anil, 2007; Olano-Martin et al., 2010), who may constitute 25% of the Caucasian population. In women, dietary saturated fat was associated with total cholesterol, and higher alphalipoic acid (ALA) intake with lower systolic blood pressure, as seen before (Takeuchi et al., 2007). Only in men was a positive correlation found between triglyceride levels and body fat, although, as Mirmiran and colleagues (2009) reported, we found no direct correlation between triglyceride level and dietary saturated fat.

It is known that body composition is influenced by metabolic response to variations in macronutrient intake. In particular, fat storage versus oxidation is largely dependent on proportional carbohydrate intake and glycogen stores, and less so on fat intake (DeLany et al., 2006). A cumulative increase in positive fat balance, and hence adiposity, leads to increased free fatty acid flux, and decreased insulin sensitivity. Furthermore, quality of fat may have an effect, dependent on degree of unsaturation of the fatty acid and number of carbon atoms in the chain (DeLany et al., 2006). Studies report that fat oxidation rates are higher after meals high in unsaturated compared with saturated fat (Casas-Agustench et al., 2009; Leyton et al., 1987; Piers et al., 2002). Furthermore, considerable evidence indicates that polyunsaturated fat influences body composition through several mechanisms including peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor (PPAR) and other transcription factors (Jump, 2008; Minihane, 2009; Raclot et al., 1997; Takahashi and Ide, 2000). Oestrogen may have an agonistic effect on PPAR activity and underlie gender differences in lipid homeostasis (D’Eon et al., 2005).

Although we appreciate that group sizes were unequal and in certain cases small, nonetheless dietary comparisons between subgroups of our university volunteers revealed similar n-3 fatty acid intakes between our nutritionally aware students and other subgroups (data not shown), which were lower than National Diet and Nutrition Survey (NDNS) data and dietary recommendations. One possible explanation is that healthcare professionals neglect their own health (Bazargan et al., 2009), or simply dislike fish (Pliner and Pelchat, 1991) despite knowing the nutritional benefits (Martins et al., 1997). Alternatively, the underlying reason may be the pressure on student budgets. Recent research in Japan reported an association between socioeconomic status and BMI in dietetics students (Murakami et al., 2009), and lower EPA and DHA intake (0.2% of energy intake) than their qualified peers (0.38% and 0.45% mean energy intakes in younger and older subgroups, respectively) (Kuriki et al., 2002). Higher intakes associated with age observed in the Kuriki study may also partially explain results in our young students. Nevertheless, saturated fat and omega-6 intakes (and consequently omega-6:omega-3) in our nutritionally aware female students were lower than those seen in female staff and other students. Thus, in spite of low omega-3 intake, findings on the whole demonstrated greater adoption of healthy eating principles in nutritionally aware female students. In contrast, in men, with greater potential to benefit from a modified fat diet, fat intake did not differ between nutritionally aware students and other subgroups. In light of findings from this study, therefore, how can we realistically expect a nutritionally unaware, lower socioeconomic East London population, arguably at greater cardiovascular risk, to achieve current dietary recommendations for omega-3 fatty acids?

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: It is salutary to note that subjects in our study consumed less saturated fat than observed nationally. Whilst this may reflect the fact that many had an interest in nutritional issues, it also points to the refractory nature of dietary change because their intake of unsaturated fats did not meet recommended values. It has been previously recognised that undergraduates studying in university nutrition departments fail to achieve recommendations in their own diets (Brown et al., 2005). Conversely, inclusion of active teaching on the benefits of a healthy ‘Mediterranean’ diet can change the diet of Northern European nutrition students (Van Diepen et al., 2010). This paradox might also lie at the heart of our findings.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors wish to thank staff and students of London Metropolitan University for volunteering for this study, and Professor Robert Gilchrist (PhD Stats), London Metropolitan University, for his statistical advice. KG, YM and MC conceived and designed the study; MN and JG recruited volunteers and collected the data; MN and GG analysed and interpreted the data; MN wrote the present paper. All authors critically reviewed the manuscript and approved the final version submitted for publication.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This study was supported by the Marie Curie Actions – Transfer of Knowledge (MTKD-CT-2005-029914).

fn.label: Declaration of conflicting interests
fn.p: All authors declare that they have no conflict of interest.
